concepts.title: About the Poem and Poet
concepts.content: Emily Bront√´ was a well-known British author who lived in the nineteenth century. She uses nature to express her thoughts and feelings. This poem presents time (past, present, future) as a dialogue between the poet and a happy child. It shows that the past was pleasant but gone, the present is a time of preparation, and the future is unknown but exciting.

examples.text: Past: a soft autumn evening ‚Äî pleasant but ended
Present: a young bird gathering strength to fly away
Future: a mighty, dazzling sea stretching to infinity
Emily and her sisters Charlotte and Anne were all famous writers

keyPoints: Emily Bront√´: 19th century British author
Poem is a dialogue between the poet and a child
Nature images represent time: autumn, bird, sea
Past = pleasant but cannot return to it
Future = unknown but exciting and infinite
concepts.funFact: üìö Emily Bront√´ also wrote the famous novel 'Wuthering Heights' ‚Äî one of the greatest love stories in English literature!
concepts.textbookRef: Page 1: Past, Present, Future by Emily Bront√´

concepts.title: Understanding the Poem
concepts.content: The poem uses three nature images: (1) Past = 'An Autumn evening soft and mild with a wind that sighs mournfully' (2) Present = 'A green and flowery spray where a young bird sits gathering its power to mount and fly away' (3) Future = 'A sea beneath a cloudless sun; a mighty, glorious, dazzling sea stretching into infinity.'

examples.text: Past: sad (wind sighs mournfully) but pleasant ‚Äî like a sweet memory
Present: active ‚Äî the bird is 'gathering power', preparing for flight
Future: 'stretching into infinity' ‚Äî limitless possibility
Dialogue form: poet asks, child answers in quotes

keyPoints: Three stanzas = three time periods
Autumn = end of something (past is gone)
Bird gathering strength = preparing for the future (present)
Dazzling sea = vast, exciting, unknown future
Rhyme scheme: thee/free, spray/away, one/sun
concepts.funFact: üê¶ A young bird 'gathering its power to fly' is a perfect image of a student at school ‚Äî preparing for the big wide future!

concepts.title: Reading Aloud ‚Äî Rhythm and Intonation
concepts.content: Poetry should be read aloud with proper rhythm (the beat of the poem) and intonation (the rise and fall of the voice). Questions in the poem are read with rising intonation. Answers are read with a thoughtful, slightly falling intonation. The mood changes ‚Äî mournful for the past, hopeful for the present, excited for the future.

examples.text: Rise in pitch for questions: 'What the past is like to thee?'
Slower, softer for past: 'An Autumn evening soft and mild'
Excited, louder for future: 'A mighty, glorious, dazzling sea!'
Rhythm: regular beat makes poem musical and memorable

keyPoints: Rhythm: regular beat in poetry ‚Äî clap while reading to find it
Intonation: rise for questions, fall for statements
Mood shifts: mournful ‚Üí hopeful ‚Üí excited across stanzas
Read dialogue parts as actual conversation
Slow down for emotional lines; speed up for energetic ones
concepts.funFact: üéµ Poetry was originally sung, not read ‚Äî that's why it has rhythm and beat, just like your favourite songs!

concepts.title: Simile ‚Äî Comparison Using 'as' or 'like'
concepts.content: A simile is an imaginative comparison of two different things that have something in common. A simile always includes the words 'as' or 'like'. For example: 'as tall as a tree', 'as lovely as a flower', 'runs like the wind'. Similes make descriptions vivid and easy to picture.

examples.text: 'as tall as a tree' ‚Äî person's height compared to a tree
'runs like the wind' ‚Äî speed compared to wind
'as lovely as a flower' ‚Äî beauty compared to a flower
From poem: 'Fly as thick as driving rain' (sights flying past)

keyPoints: Simile: imaginative comparison of two different things
Always uses 'as' or 'like'
Both things share one common quality
Makes writing more vivid and descriptive
Examples: as bright as the sun; cried like a baby
concepts.funFact: ‚úçÔ∏è Ancient Indian poets used similes extensively ‚Äî in Sanskrit poetry, the technique is called 'Upama' and is considered the queen of literary devices!

concepts.title: Metaphor ‚Äî Direct Comparison Without 'as' or 'like'
concepts.content: A metaphor makes a direct comparison without using 'as' or 'like'. It says something IS another thing. For example: 'He is a gem of a person', 'Time is money', 'Books are our friends', 'The clouds are white sheep'. The poem 'Past, Present, Future' has three metaphors ‚Äî the past IS an autumn evening, the present IS a flowery spray, the future IS a sea.

examples.text: 'He is a gem of a person' ‚Äî person IS a gem (precious)
'Time is money' ‚Äî time IS money (don't waste either)
'Books are our friends' ‚Äî books ARE friends (helpful, loyal)
'The clouds are white sheep' ‚Äî clouds ARE sheep (fluffy, moving)

keyPoints: Metaphor: direct comparison without 'as'/'like'
Says something IS something else
Implies qualities without explaining them
Stronger and more direct than simile
Poem has 3 metaphors: past=autumn evening, present=flowery spray, future=sea
concepts.funFact: üåç Shakespeare used more metaphors than any other writer ‚Äî he created phrases like 'All the world's a stage' that we still use today!

test.question: In the poem, what is the present hour compared to?
options: A green and flowery spray where a young bird sits
A sea beneath a cloudless sun
test.explanation: 'The present hour? A green and flowery spray where a young bird sits gathering its power to mount and fly away.'

test.question: 'As lovely as a flower' is an example of _____.
test.explanation: A simile compares two things using 'as' or 'like'. 'As lovely as a flower' uses 'as' ‚Äî it is a simile.

test.question: 'Time is money' is an example of _____.
test.explanation: A metaphor says something IS something else without 'as'/'like'. 'Time is money' says time directly IS money.

test.question: How does the poem describe the future?
options: A mighty, glorious, dazzling sea stretching into infinity
A young bird on a spray
test.explanation: 'And what is the future? A sea beneath a cloudless sun; a mighty, glorious, dazzling sea stretching into infinity.'

test.question: The poem is presented as a _____.
options: Dialogue between poet and a child
test.explanation: The poem is in dialogue form ‚Äî the poet asks questions ('Tell me, tell me, smiling child') and the child answers.

test.question: Which of these uses 'like' to make a simile?
test.explanation: 'She sings like a bird' uses 'like' to compare her singing to a bird's ‚Äî it is a simile.

test.question: How many metaphors are there in the poem?
test.explanation: Three metaphors: past IS an autumn evening, present IS a flowery spray where a bird sits, future IS a sea.

test.question: Which century did Emily Bront√´ live in?
test.explanation: Emily Bront√´ and her sisters were well-known authors who lived in the nineteenth century (1800s).

test.question: The wind in the autumn evening is described as _____.
test.explanation: 'An Autumn evening soft and mild with a wind that sighs mournfully' ‚Äî the wind sighs mournfully.

test.question: 'The clouds are white sheep' ‚Äî what device is this?
test.explanation: Metaphor ‚Äî says clouds ARE sheep without using 'as' or 'like'. Direct comparison.

keyConcepts: Emily Bront√´: 19th century British poet, also wrote Wuthering Heights
Poem structure: dialogue between poet and child about past, present, future
Past = autumn evening (pleasant but gone); Present = bird gathering strength; Future = dazzling sea
Simile: comparison using 'as' or 'like' (e.g., as tall as a tree)
Metaphor: direct comparison without 'as'/'like' (e.g., Books are our friends)
Three metaphors in the poem for past, present and future
commonMisconceptions: All comparisons are similes ‚Äî FALSE, metaphors compare without 'as'/'like'
The poem is sad ‚Äî the future is described as exciting and infinite
Metaphor = exaggeration ‚Äî FALSE, metaphor is a type of comparison
realWorldExamples: Mumbai rains = silver rain (connect to Langston Hughes)
School life now = gathering strength like the bird in present stanza
Exam results = mournful autumn or dazzling sea depending on result!

longAnswers.question: Explain how the poem imagines the Past, Present, and Future through nature images.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The poem presents time as a moving natural landscape. The Past appears distant and fading, like something seen through memory. The Present is shown as fresh and living, full of colour and immediate sensation. The Future appears uncertain yet inviting, suggesting hope mixed with mystery. By using nature images, the poet makes abstract time feel visible and emotional for young readers.
keyPoints: Past, present, and future are personified through imagery.
Nature symbols make the idea of time concrete.
Each time-zone carries a distinct emotional tone.

longAnswers.question: What does the ‚Äúgreen and flowery spray‚Äù suggest in the poem? Why is a young bird mentioned there?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The ‚Äúgreen and flowery spray‚Äù suggests freshness, growth, and the beauty of life in bloom, symbolizing the vitality of the present moment. The young bird adds a sense of innocence, beginning, and lively movement. Together they represent youth, possibility, and the joyful energy of life now unfolding. The poet uses these images to make the present feel bright and alive.
keyPoints: Green flowery spray symbolizes freshness and growth.
Young bird symbolizes innocence and new beginnings.
Combined imagery highlights the vibrancy of the present.

longAnswers.question: How is the Future described in the poem, and what feeling does it create?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The Future is described as something not fully seen‚Äîopen, distant, and partly unknown. This creates a mixed feeling of curiosity and expectation rather than fear. The poet suggests that the future is not fixed; it unfolds gradually as life moves ahead. The tone remains hopeful, encouraging readers to look forward with imagination.
keyPoints: Future is shown as uncertain but promising.
Tone evokes curiosity and hope.
Poem encourages forward-looking imagination.

longAnswers.question: Write a short note on the emotional message of the poem ‚ÄúPast, Present, Future‚Äù.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: The poem encourages readers to value memory without getting trapped in it, to enjoy the beauty of the present, and to welcome the future with optimism. It suggests that life is a journey across changing moments, each with meaning. The emotional message is balanced and gentle: cherish what was, live what is, and trust what may come.
keyPoints: Balanced attitude toward all three time dimensions.
Encourages mindful living in the present.
Promotes hopeful outlook toward future.

longAnswers.question: Language study: Differentiate simile and metaphor with examples.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: A simile is an explicit comparison using words like ‚Äúas‚Äù or ‚Äúlike‚Äù (for example, ‚Äúas bright as the sun‚Äù). A metaphor is an implied comparison without ‚Äúas/like‚Äù (for example, ‚Äútime is a river‚Äù). Simile tells that one thing is like another, while metaphor directly states one thing as another for stronger poetic effect.
keyPoints: Simile uses ‚Äúas/like‚Äù for direct comparison.
Metaphor compares without comparative markers.
Both add imagery and depth to poetic language.

longAnswers.question: Creative response: Write a brief reflection on your own past, present, and future in 6‚Äì8 lines.
longAnswers.modelAnswer: My past is full of memories that taught me patience and courage. My present is a time to learn, grow, and improve each day. I try to stay grateful for what I have and work honestly for what I want. My future feels unknown, but I see it as a field of possibilities. I want to carry good values from my past, act responsibly in the present, and build a meaningful tomorrow.
keyPoints: Include personal reflection across all three time phases.
Show continuity of values and growth.
Use simple but thoughtful language.
